noun.description: An act of selecting or making a decision when faced with two or more possibilities.
examples: the choice between good and evil

adjective.description: (especially of food) of very good quality.
examples: he picked some choice early plums

adjective.description: (of words, phrases, or language) rude and abusive.
examples: he had a few choice words at his command

phrases: There was no starving to death by choice or through circumstance, only hunger.
Yet, they insist, they are performers by birth and caste, not by choice.
You love change and use it to your advantage, whether by choice or by chance.
Not the place you would want to work by choice, but our intrepid weather officer just needs a little more time.
If you're going to write, you might as well know the rules, so then if you break them, at least it will be by choice.
origin: Middle English: from Old French chois, from choisir choose, of Germanic origin and related to choose.
